item.title: Dijkstra's Algorithm in Java
item.description:
Wrote an implementation of Dijkstra’s algorithm in Java using a PriorityQueue. The code is quite simple (only 50 lines).

import java.util.*;
class Graph {
	Map<Integer, Set<Edge>> edges = new HashMap<>();
	Map<Integer, Integer> dists;

	void addVertex(int i) {
		edges.put(i, new HashSet<>());
	}

	void addEdge(int src, int dst, int w) {
		edges.get(src).add(new Edge(src, dst, w));
	}

	void addUndirectedEdge(int src, int dst, int w) {
		addEdge(src, dst, w);
		addEdge(dst, src, w);
	}

	Map<Integer, Integer> getDistancesFrom(int iStart) {
		dists = new HashMap<>();
		dists.put(iStart, 0);
		PriorityQueue<Edge> pq = new PriorityQueue<Edge>();
		pq.addAll(edges.get(iStart));
		while (!pq.isEmpty()) {
			Edge e = pq.poll();
			if (!dists.containsKey(e.dst)) {
				dists.put(e.dst, e.dist());
				pq.addAll(edges.get(e.dst));
			}
		}
		return new HashMap<>(dists);
	}

	class Edge implements Comparable<Edge> {
		int src;
		int dst;
		int w;

		public Edge(int src, int dst, int w) {
			this.src = src;
			this.dst = dst;
			this.w = w;
		}

		public int compareTo(Edge e) {
			return Integer.compare(this.dist(), e.dist());
		}

		int dist() {
			return dists.get(src) + w;
		}
	}
}

And a simple test case:

Graph g = new Graph();
g.addVertex(1);
g.addVertex(2);
g.addVertex(3);
g.addEdge(1, 2, 5);
g.addEdge(2, 3, 15);
g.addEdge(1, 3, 21);
System.out.println(g.getDistancesFrom(1).get(3));

This will print 20, the shortest distance between vertex 1 and vertex 3.

item.title: Unexpected JVM Behavior
item.description:
Here’s a disassembled classfile (Test.class):

Classfile format major version: 50, minor version: 0.
Access flags: public super
Field name: x Signature: static int
Method name: "<clinit>" Signature: ()void
  0: iconst_1
  1: putstatic <Field Test.x int>
  4: return
Method name: "main" Signature: public static (java.lang.String[])void
  0: getstatic <Field java.lang.System.out java.io.PrintStream>
  3: getstatic <Field Test.x int>
  6: invokevirtual <Method java.io.PrintStream.println (int)void>
  9: return

This classfile roughly corresponds to the following Java code:

public class Test {
	static int x;
	static {
		x = 1;
	}
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		System.out.println(x);
	}
}

So what happens when we run this classfile? The main method prints 1, as we would expect.

However…​ if we change the classfile format major version from 50 (Java 1.6) to 51 (Java 1.7)…​ then the main method prints 0! The JVM doesn’t run the <clinit> method.

If you look back at the disassembled classfile, you might notice that the <clinit> method is not static (that is, it doesn’t have the ACC_STATIC flag set). Surprisingly, JVM version 1.6 didn’t care whether or not <clinit> methods are defined as static. When this issue was reported in 2009, the fix was to disallow non-static <clinit> methods when the classfile major version is greater than 50 (for backwards compatibility). I ran into this quirk while working on sJava, but as usual reading the JVM Specification would have saved me some trouble:

In a class file whose version number is 51.0 or above, the method [<clinit>] must additionally have its ACC_STATIC flag (ยง4.6) set in order to be the class or interface initialization method.
— https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jvms/se8/html/jvms-2.html#jvms-2.9
